Development reference containing: (1) Detailed fix instructions for Jules PR #4 security issues on vibe-code-news, and (2) Complete Smart Router architecture documentation explaining the 3-tier model routing system (Tier 1 dispatchers â†’ Tier 2 responders â†’ Chairman synthesis).

Full Report

TRAE â€” Development Reference

Repo: Nadav-Fux/Vibe-Coding-News-App-TRAE Â |Â  Branch: dev-upgrade-stack-ai-v1-14977213683973218375

JULES â€” PR #4 Security Fixes

Source: JULES-FIX-INSTRUCTIONS.md

Context

Claude reviewed PR #4 on Nadav-Fux/Vibe-Coding-News-App-TRAE. The architecture is solid and the provider pattern is well-designed. However, there are 6 critical security issues and several warnings that need fixing before merge.

Work on the same branch: dev-upgrade-stack-ai-v1-14977213683973218375

CRITICAL FIXES â€” All 6 Must Be Done

Fix 1: Quick-Admin-Login Production Guard

File: src/app/api/auth/quick/route.ts

The endpoint has zero environment protection. In production, anyone can visit /api/auth/quick and become admin.

Required change:

export async function GET() {
  // TODO: REMOVE BEFORE PRODUCTION â€” development convenience only
  if (process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production' && !process.env.ALLOW_QUICK_LOGIN) {
    return NextResponse.json(
      { error: 'Quick login disabled in production' },
      { status: 403 }
    );
  }
  // ... rest of existing logic
}

Fix 2: Middleware Must Validate Auth Tokens

File: src/middleware.ts

Currently the middleware only checks if a cookie EXISTS â€” any value (including mock-token-for-development) passes. The cookie presence check is not authentication.

Required change:

import { createClient } from '@supabase/supabase-js';

// Inside the admin route protection block:
const sessionCookie = request.cookies.get('sb-access-token')?.value ||
                     request.cookies.get('supabase-auth-token')?.value;

if (!sessionCookie) {
  return NextResponse.redirect(new URL('/auth/login', request.url));
}

// In production, verify the token is real (not just present)
if (process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production') {
  const supabase = createClient(
    process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_URL!,
    process.env.NEXT_PUBLIC_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY!
  );
  const { data: { user }, error } = await supabase.auth.getUser(sessionCookie);
  if (error || !user) {
    return NextResponse.redirect(new URL('/auth/login', request.url));
  }
}
// In dev, allow mock tokens to pass (for quick-admin-login)

Fix 3: Privacy Export Requires Authentication

File: src/app/api/privacy/export/route.ts

This endpoint currently lets ANYONE submit ANY email and get that user's full data. It uses supabaseAdmin (service role), bypassing all RLS.

Required change:

export async function POST(request: NextRequest) {
  // Verify the requesting user is authenticated
  const authHeader = request.headers.get('authorization');
  const token = authHeader?.replace('Bearer ', '') ||
                request.cookies.get('sb-access-token')?.value;

  if (!token) {
    return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Authentication required' }, { status: 401 });
  }

  const { data: { user }, error: authError } = await supabaseAdmin.auth.getUser(token);
  if (authError || !user) {
    return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Invalid session' }, { status: 401 });
  }

  // Only allow users to export their OWN data
  const { email } = await request.json();
  if (user.email !== email) {
    return NextResponse.json({ error: 'You can only export your own data' }, { status: 403 });
  }

  // ... rest of existing export logic
}

Fix 4: Sanitize Tags in Recommendations API

File: src/app/api/ai/recommendations/route.ts

AI-generated tags are interpolated directly into .or() filter string â€” this is injectable.

Required change:

// BEFORE (vulnerable):
.or(`title.ilike.%${tags[0]}%,excerpt.ilike.%${tags[0]}%`)

// AFTER (safe):
// Sanitize tags: remove special characters, limit length
const sanitizeTag = (tag: string) => tag.replace(/[^a-zA-Z0-9\u0590-\u05FF\s-]/g, '').slice(0, 50);
const safeTag = sanitizeTag(tags[0]);
// Use separate .ilike() calls instead of .or() string building:
const { data: articles } = await supabase
  .from('articles')
  .select('id, title, slug, excerpt, featured_image')
  .or(`title.ilike.%${safeTag}%,excerpt.ilike.%${safeTag}%`)
  .neq('id', articleId)
  .eq('status', 'published')
  .limit(limit);

The key change is the sanitizeTag function that strips special characters (keeping Hebrew \u0590-\u05FF range).

Fix 5: Scraper Needs Auth + URL Validation

File: src/app/api/scraper/run/route.ts

Two problems: no authentication (anyone can trigger scrapes) and SSRF (can target internal network).

Required change:

export async function POST(request: NextRequest) {
  // 1. Require admin authentication
  const token = request.cookies.get('sb-access-token')?.value;
  if (!token) {
    return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Admin access required' }, { status: 401 });
  }

  const { url, source_type = 'html' } = await request.json();

  // 2. URL validation â€” block internal networks (SSRF prevention)
  try {
    const parsed = new URL(url);
    if (!['http:', 'https:'].includes(parsed.protocol)) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Only HTTP(S) URLs allowed' }, { status: 400 });
    }
    const hostname = parsed.hostname;
    // Block internal/private IPs
    const blocked = [
      /^localhost$/i, /^127\./, /^10\./, /^172\.(1[6-9]|2\d|3[01])\./, /^192\.168\./,
      /^0\./, /^169\.254\./, /^::1$/, /^fc00:/i, /^fe80:/i
    ];
    if (blocked.some(pattern => pattern.test(hostname))) {
      return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Internal URLs not allowed' }, { status: 400 });
    }
  } catch {
    return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Invalid URL' }, { status: 400 });
  }

  // ... rest of existing scraper logic
}

Fix 6: Enable CSRF Enforcement

File: src/middleware.ts

CSRF check currently only logs â€” the enforcement return is commented out.

Required change â€” uncomment the enforcement block:

// BEFORE:
// TODO: Uncomment to enforce strict CSRF in production
// return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Invalid CSRF Token' }, { status: 403 })

// AFTER:
if (process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production') {
  return NextResponse.json({ error: 'Invalid CSRF Token' }, { status: 403 });
}
console.warn('[CSRF] Token mismatch â€” would block in production');

Also in src/lib/security/csrf.ts, fix the timing-safe comparison:

import { timingSafeEqual } from 'crypto';

export function validateCsrfToken(tokenFromHeader: string, tokenFromCookie: string): boolean {
  if (tokenFromHeader.length !== tokenFromCookie.length) return false;
  return timingSafeEqual(
    Buffer.from(tokenFromHeader),
    Buffer.from(tokenFromCookie)
  );
}

WARNING FIXES â€” Important but Non-Blocking

Fix 7: Rate Limiter â€” Replace cache.clear() with per-entry TTL

File: src/lib/security/rate-limit.ts

// BEFORE: nuclear option â€” clears ALL entries
if (cache.size > uniqueTokenPerInterval) {
  cache.clear();
}

// AFTER: evict only expired entries
const now = Date.now();
for (const [key, entry] of cache.entries()) {
  if (now - entry.timestamp > interval) {
    cache.delete(key);
  }
}

Fix 8: Resolve cover_image vs featured_image

File: supabase/migrations/001_core_schema.sql

Pick ONE column name. The TRAE codebase uses featured_image in components. Remove cover_image from the migration:

-- Remove this line:
-- cover_image TEXT,
-- Keep only:
featured_image TEXT,

Then search all code for cover_image and replace with featured_image.

Fix 9: Search API Improvements

File: src/app/api/search/route.ts

Three fixes:

1. Use server-side Supabase client:

import { supabaseAdmin } from '@/lib/supabase/server';

2. Add ts_headline for highlighted results via RPC. Add to migration:

CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION search_articles(search_query text, result_limit int DEFAULT 20)
RETURNS TABLE(id uuid, title text, slug text, excerpt text, featured_image text, headline text, rank real)
AS $$
  SELECT a.id, a.title, a.slug, a.excerpt, a.featured_image,
    ts_headline('english', a.content, websearch_to_tsquery('english', search_query),
      'StartSel=<mark>, StopSel=</mark>, MaxWords=50, MinWords=20') as headline,
    ts_rank(a.search_vector, websearch_to_tsquery('english', search_query)) as rank
  FROM articles a
  WHERE a.search_vector @@ websearch_to_tsquery('english', search_query)
    AND a.status = 'published'
  ORDER BY rank DESC
  LIMIT result_limit;
$$ LANGUAGE sql STABLE;

Then call via: supabaseAdmin.rpc('search_articles', { search_query: q, result_limit: limit })

3. Either implement tag filtering or remove the tag parameter from the API.

Fix 10: FTS Text Search Config for Hebrew

File: supabase/migrations/001_core_schema.sql

Change 'english' to 'simple' in the trigger function. The 'simple' config works for any language (no stemming, just tokenization):

NEW.search_vector := to_tsvector('simple', coalesce(NEW.title, '') || ' ' || coalesce(NEW.content, ''));

Fix 11: GLM Model Label Consistency

File: src/lib/ai/glm.ts

If the model is glm-4-plus, label it as such in the UI. Either:

  • Update the model to glm-5 if ZhipuAI API supports it
  • Or change the UI label to "GLM-4-Plus" in src/components/admin/ai-provider-settings.tsx

NEW FEATURE: Smart AI Router (Phase 2.5)

Do NOT implement this yet.

This is context for the next iteration. After the fixes above are merged, we will add an intelligent routing layer to the AI gateway. The architecture:

  1. Triage model (Groq/Cerebras, fastest) classifies incoming requests
  2. Simple requests â€” single fast model responds directly
  3. Complex requests â€” council mode with multiple models
  4. Tool-augmented requests â€” web scraping, image generation, etc.

This will be a separate PR. Focus on the security fixes for now.

Smart AI Router Architecture

Source: SMART-ROUTER-ARCHITECTURE.md Â |Â  Vibe Code News TRAE

Based On

  • Spark's actual council router (/root/llm-council/backend/ on 77.90.40.84) â€” battle-tested, running in production
  • Karpathy's LLM Council â€” 3-stage deliberation with anonymized peer review
  • RouteLLM (LMSYS) â€” cost-quality routing with learned classifiers
  • Mixture of Agents (Together AI) â€” iterative refinement through model layers

How Spark Does It (What Works)

Spark runs a FastAPI server (/root/llm-council/backend/smart_router.py) on port 8001 that provides two modes:

Mode 1: Smart Router (daily use)

Request â†’ Keyword detection â†’ Tier classification (fast/smart) â†’ Candidate selection â†’ Failover chain
  • Keyword shortcuts: "flash:", "glm:", "pro:" (+ Hebrew: "×¤×œ××©", "×’×œ×") bypass triage and go straight to a model
  • Tier detection: Messages >1000 chars OR containing trigger words â†’ "smart" tier. Everything else â†’ "fast" tier
  • Context-aware candidates: Estimated token count determines which models are eligible
  • Per-model fallback chains: Every model has its own fallback list. Every chain ends at GLM-5
  • Groq round-robin: 2 API keys rotated for load distribution

Mode 2: Full Council (deliberation for hard questions)

Stage 0: Fast model selects which 3-4 models to consult
Stage 1: All selected models answer in parallel
Stage 2: All models ANONYMOUSLY peer-review each other's answers â†’ Elo ratings
Stage 3: Chairman (GLM-5) synthesizes the best answer using rankings as signal

Key insight from Karpathy: Anonymization prevents self-bias â€” models can't play favorites when they don't know which response is theirs.

  for (const review of reviews) {
    review.ranking.forEach((label, position) => {
      positionScores[label] = positionScores[label] || [];
      positionScores[label].push(position + 1);
    });
  }
  return Object.entries(positionScores)
    .map(([label, positions]) => ({
      label,
      avgRank: positions.reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0) / positions.length,
    }))
    .sort((a, b) => a.avgRank - b.avgRank);
}

async webSearch(query: string): Promise<ToolResult> {

How Spark Does It (What Works)

Spark runs a FastAPI server (/root/llm-council/backend/smart_router.py) on port 8001 that provides two modes:

Mode 1: Smart Router (daily use)

Request â†’ Keyword detection â†’ Tier classification (fast/smart) â†’ Candidate selection â†’ Failover chain
  • Keyword shortcuts: "flash:", "glm:", "pro:" (+ Hebrew: "×¤×œ××©", "×’×œ×") bypass triage and go straight to a model
  • Tier detection: Messages >1000 chars OR containing trigger words â†’ "smart" tier. Everything else â†’ "fast" tier
  • Context-aware candidates: Estimated token count determines which models are eligible
  • Per-model fallback chains: Every model has its own fallback list. Every chain ends at GLM-5
  • Groq round-robin: 2 API keys rotated for load distribution

Mode 2: Full Council (deliberation for hard questions)

Stage 0: Fast model selects which 3-4 models to consult
Stage 1: All selected models answer in parallel
Stage 2: All models ANONYMOUSLY peer-review each other's answers â†’ Elo ratings
Stage 3: Chairman (GLM-5) synthesizes the best answer using rankings as signal

Key insight from Karpathy: Anonymization prevents self-bias â€” models can't play favorites when they don't know which response is theirs.

function quickClassify(message: string): 'fast' | 'smart' | null {
  // Short messages â†’ fast
  if (message.length < 200) return 'fast';

  // Trigger words â†’ smart

  // Can't decide â†’ let LLM triage

Council Mode

// Aggregation: Average rank position across all reviewers
function aggregateRankings(reviews: Review[]): RankedResponse[] {
  const positionScores: Record<string, number[]> = {};
  for (const review of reviews) {
    review.ranking.forEach((label, position) => {
      positionScores[label] = positionScores[label] || [];
      positionScores[label].push(position + 1);
    });
  }
  return Object.entries(positionScores)
    .map(([label, positions]) => ({
      label,
      avgRank: positions.reduce((a, b) => a + b, 0) / positions.length,
    }))
    .sort((a, b) => a.avgRank - b.avgRank);
}

Tool Execution Pattern:

// Web Search â€” SerpAPI with DuckDuckGo fallback
async webSearch(query: string): Promise<ToolResult> {
  if (process.env.SERPAPI_KEY) {
    const url = `https://serpapi.com/search?q=${encodeURIComponent(query)}&api_key=${process.env.SERPAPI_KEY}&num=5`;
    const res = await fetch(url, { signal: AbortSignal.timeout(10000) });
    const data = await res.json();
    return { success: true, content: data.organic_results?.map((r: any) =>
      `**${r.title}**\n${r.snippet}\nSource: ${r.link}`
    ).join('\n\n') || 'No results found' };
  }
  // Fallback: DuckDuckGo (no key needed)
  const url = `https://api.duckduckgo.com/?q=${encodeURIComponent(query)}&format=json&no_html=1`;
  const res = await fetch(url, { signal: AbortSignal.timeout(5000) });
  const data = await res.json();
  return { success: true, content: data.AbstractText || data.Answer || 'No results' };
}

// Image Generation â€” Pollinations (free, always available)
async generateImage(prompt: string): Promise<ToolResult> {
  const imageUrl = `https://image.pollinations.ai/prompt/${encodeURIComponent(prompt)}?width=1200&height=630&nologo=true`;
  return { success: true, content: imageUrl, type: 'image_url' };
}

// Web Scrape â€” Cheerio for static HTML
async webScrape(url: string): Promise<ToolResult> {
  const res = await fetch(url, {
    signal: AbortSignal.timeout(10000),
    headers: { 'User-Agent': 'VibeCrawler/1.0' }
  });
  const html = await res.text();
  const cheerio = await import('cheerio');
  const $ = cheerio.load(html);
  $('script, style, nav, footer, header, aside').remove();
  const text = $('article, main, .content, .post-body, body').first().text()
    .replace(/\s+/g, ' ').trim().slice(0, 5000);
  return { success: true, content: text };
}

Executive Summary

Upgrade plan for the vibe-code-news app to be implemented by Jules AI agent: stack modernization, security hardening, performance optimization, and feature additions. Includes code review findings and prioritized implementation order.

Full Report

TRAE Vibe Code News â€” Upgrade Plan for Jules + Review

This is the comprehensive upgrade plan for Jules to implement on the Nadav-Fux/Vibe-Coding-News-App-TRAE repository (Development branch). It covers all 8 phases: stack upgrade, AI provider overhaul, Supabase schema, security hardening, feature porting from v0-Ver02, code cleanup, deployment, and final verification.

Following the plan is a full Claude review of what TRAE already does well, what needs the most attention, a risk assessment, and answers to Jules's implementation questions.

Repo: Nadav-Fux/Vibe-Coding-News-App-TRAE â€” branch: Development
Who executes: Jules (Google's AI coding agent) implements. Claude reviews and fixes afterward.
Deploy target: Vercel + Cloudflare free tier

Phase 1

Stack Upgrade

PackageCurrentTarget
Next.js15.0.315.3.x (latest stable 15)
React18.3.119.x
TypeScript5.2.05.7.x
Tailwind CSS3.3.04.x (or stay on 3.4.x â€” see note)

Why not Next.js 16?

Next.js 16 had CVE-2025-66478 and is very new. Stick with latest 15.x for stability.

Files to modify

  • package.json â€” Update all dependency versions
  • tailwind.config.ts â€” Migrate to Tailwind v4 CSS-first config (or keep v3 config with compat)
  • postcss.config.mjs â€” Update for Tailwind v4
  • tsconfig.json â€” Update compiler options for TS 5.7
  • next.config.ts â€” Review for deprecated options
  • All component files using className â€” Verify Tailwind v4 class compatibility

Steps

  1. Update package.json dependencies:
next: "^15.3.0"
react: "^19.0.0"
react-dom: "^19.0.0"
typescript: "~5.7.0"
tailwindcss: "^4.1.0"
@tailwindcss/postcss: "^4.1.0"  # NEW - replaces tailwindcss in postcss
  1. Remove tailwind.config.ts â€” migrate to CSS-first config in src/app/globals.css:
@import "tailwindcss";
@theme {
  /* port existing theme from tailwind.config.ts */
}
  1. Update postcss.config.mjs:
export default { plugins: { "@tailwindcss/postcss": {} } }
  1. Fix React 19 breaking changes (ref as prop, no forwardRef needed, useFormStatus changes)
  2. Run pnpm install and fix type errors
  3. Verify build passes: pnpm build

Tailwind v4 Migration Notes

  • bg-opacity-* â†’ bg-{color}/{opacity} (e.g., bg-black/50)
  • dark: variant still works
  • @apply still works but discouraged for new code
  • Custom colors/spacing from tailwind.config.ts â†’ @theme block in CSS
  • If migration is too complex, stay on Tailwind 3.4.x instead. Don't break the UI.
Phase 2

AI Provider Overhaul

DirectionProviders
CurrentGemini (gemini-2.5-flash), GLM 4.6 (glm-4-plus), MiniMax (abab6.5s-chat)
TargetGLM-5, Groq, Cerebras, Nvidia NIM, Gemini, Cloudflare AI Workers

Files to modify

  • src/lib/ai/ai-gateway.ts â€” Add new providers, update fallback chain
  • src/lib/ai/glm.ts â€” Update to GLM-5 endpoint
  • src/lib/ai/gemini.ts â€” Keep as-is
  • src/lib/ai/minimax.ts â€” DELETE this file
  • NEW src/lib/ai/groq.ts
  • NEW src/lib/ai/cerebras.ts
  • NEW src/lib/ai/nvidia.ts
  • NEW src/lib/ai/cloudflare.ts
  • .env.example â€” Add new env vars

New Provider Implementations

// Uses: process.env.CLOUDFLARE_ACCOUNT_ID + process.env.CLOUDFLARE_API_TOKEN

Updated Fallback Chain

Each provider implements the same interface: { generateContent(prompt, options): Promise<string> }

Available API Keys

  • ZAI_API_KEY â€” GLM/ZhipuAI (already have)

  • GEMINI_API_KEY â€” user will provide later
  • CEREBRAS_API_KEY â€” user will provide later
  • NVIDIA_API_KEY â€” user will provide later

Important: All providers must gracefully skip if their API key is missing â€” no crash, just log a warning and try the next provider.

Phase 3

Supabase Schema & Database

Current state: Supabase project iboroipmdnmwworqiypi has 27 tables from v0-Ver02 migrations. TRAE expects a different schema.

Approach: Don't touch existing Supabase tables directly. Create a migration SQL file that Jules adds to the repo only (do not run it).

Files to create/modify

  • supabase/migrations/001_core_schema.sql â€” Complete schema DDL
  • supabase/FIX_NOW.sql â€” DELETE this file (outdated)
  • src/lib/supabase/client.ts â€” Verify correct initialization
  • src/lib/supabase/server.ts â€” Verify service role client
  • src/lib/supabase/queries.ts â€” Update query helpers

Target Schema

-- Core tables
profiles (id uuid PK â†’ auth.users, email, display_name, avatar_url, bio, role, created_at, updated_at)
categories (id uuid PK, name, slug UNIQUE, description, created_at)
tags (id uuid PK, name UNIQUE, slug UNIQUE, created_at)
articles (id uuid PK, title, slug UNIQUE, content, excerpt, cover_image,
          author_id â†’ profiles, category_id â†’ categories,
          status, views, published_at, created_at, updated_at, search_vector tsvector)
article_tags (article_id â†’ articles, tag_id â†’ tags, PK composite)
comments (id uuid PK, article_id â†’ articles, author_id â†’ profiles,
          content, parent_id â†’ comments, created_at, updated_at)

-- Analytics (from v0-Ver02)
analytics_events (id uuid PK, event_type, user_id â†’ profiles, article_id â†’ articles, metadata jsonb, created_at)

-- Content management
content_drafts (id uuid PK, article_id â†’ articles, content jsonb, author_id â†’ profiles, created_at)
scraped_sources (id uuid PK, name, url, source_type, config jsonb, last_scraped_at, created_at)

-- AI
ai_system_prompts (id uuid PK, name, prompt_text, category, is_active, created_at)

-- Privacy (from v0-Ver02)
privacy_consent (id uuid PK, user_id, consent_type, granted boolean, created_at)
privacy_requests (id uuid PK, user_id, request_type, status, created_at, completed_at)

RLS Policies

  • profiles: SELECT all, INSERT/UPDATE own
  • articles: SELECT published OR own, INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE own
  • comments: SELECT all, INSERT authenticated, UPDATE/DELETE own
  • categories, tags, article_tags: SELECT all, INSERT/DELETE by article author
  • analytics_events: INSERT authenticated, SELECT own
  • Service role has full access on all tables

Full-Text Search

ALTER TABLE articles ADD COLUMN IF NOT EXISTS search_vector tsvector;
CREATE INDEX idx_articles_search ON articles USING gin(search_vector);

CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION update_article_search_vector() RETURNS trigger AS $$
BEGIN
  NEW.search_vector := to_tsvector('english',
    coalesce(NEW.title, '') || ' ' ||
    coalesce(NEW.excerpt, '') || ' ' ||
    coalesce(NEW.content, ''));
  RETURN NEW;
END;
$$ LANGUAGE plpgsql;

Claude's Review Notes

What TRAE Already Does Well

  • 15+ admin themes and 7 homepage variants â€” impressive UI variety, shows real creative effort. These are deliberately preserved throughout this plan.
  • Hebrew RTL support baked in from the start â€” proper dir="rtl" and layout mirroring. Rare to see this done correctly from day one.
  • AI Gateway pattern with multi-provider fallback is architecturally sound. The abstraction layer in ai-gateway.ts is exactly the right approach for AI provider independence.
  • Zustand for state management â€” lightweight and appropriate for this scale. Not over-engineered.
  • Good component organization in src/components/ â€” clear separation of concerns.

What Needs the Most Attention

  • Auth is completely disabled (middleware allows all, NextAuth configured but not wired) â€” this is the #1 risk. Phase 4 addresses this directly.
  • AI providers are outdated (MiniMax dead, GLM on old version) â€” Phase 2 is critical and should be one of the first things Jules tackles.
  • No search functionality at all â€” v0-Ver02's PostgreSQL FTS implementation is solid and should be ported. Phase 5A covers this.
  • Supabase schema has known issues (FIX_NOW.sql documents old category column, missing meta fields, RLS not configured). Phase 3 rebuilds this properly.
  • .backup files littered through the codebase need cleanup â€” Phase 6 removes these.

Risk Assessment

Migration / ChangeRisk LevelRationale
Tailwind v4 migration HIGH Staying on v3.4.x is the right call â€” too many themes to risk breaking. If v4 migration stalls Jules, abort and pin to 3.4.x.
React 19 upgrade MEDIUM forwardRef removal and ref-as-prop changes may affect UI components. Need to scan for all forwardRef usages first.
AI provider swap LOW All new providers are OpenAI-compatible. The gateway pattern isolates changes to individual provider files.
Supabase schema rebuild MEDIUM Need to verify TRAE's query helpers match new schema column names. The SQL file approach (not running it) is safer.
Feature porting from v0-Ver02 LOW These are additive features, not modifications to existing code. Worst case: a ported feature doesn't work and gets commented out.

Jules's Questions & Answers

Q1. Which Tailwind version should I target?
Stay on v3.4.x. Do NOT migrate to v4. The risk is too high with 15+ themes. Update the version from 3.3.0 to 3.4.x (latest v3 patch), which is a non-breaking upgrade within the same major version. Save v4 migration for a future dedicated PR.
Q2. Should I run the Supabase migration SQL?
No. Add the SQL file to the repo only â€” do not execute it. The production Supabase project (iboroipmdnmwworqiypi) has 27 live tables from v0-Ver02. Running the migration could conflict with existing data. Just add supabase/migrations/001_core_schema.sql to the repo so it's ready to run when the time comes.
Q3. Can I add new npm dependencies?
Yes, add packages as needed. Specifically: if Cheerio isn't already in TRAE's deps, add it for the scraper. The pnpm lockfile will be updated accordingly. Prefer packages that are already in v0-Ver02 to keep things consistent.
Q4. How much Hebrew content should I add?
Use real Hebrew for common UI strings; placeholders for longer text. Examples of real Hebrew to use: cookie consent button (×× ×™ ××¡×›×™×), navigation items, error messages, form labels. For article content and descriptions, English placeholders are fine since that will be replaced with real content later.
Q5. What's the AI fallback order?
GLM-5 â†’ Groq â†’ Gemini â†’ Cerebras â†’ Nvidia â†’ Cloudflare AI

Rationale: GLM-5 is the primary (fastest for Hebrew content). Groq is the first fallback (free tier, very fast). Gemini is the second fallback (high quality). Cerebras and Nvidia are tertiary options. Cloudflare AI is the last resort (always available, no external API key needed beyond Cloudflare creds).

entries.summary_en: Full security audit and code review of vibeship-spark-intelligence by Claude Code (Opus 4.6). 14 total findings: 2 HIGH (API key exposure), 6 MEDIUM (token permissions, auth bypass, race conditions), 4 LOW, and 2 positive INFO findings. entries.details_en:
Repository: vibeship-spark-intelligence  |  Date: 2026-02-23  |  Auditor: Claude Code (Opus 4.6)  |  Location: Spark server (77.90.40.84)

What Is This Repo?

A Python-based intelligence/learning/advisory engine for AI coding agents (Claude Code, OpenClaw, etc.). ~200+ Python files, local-first, single-developer use. Components:

  • sparkd (port 8787) â€” main event ingestion daemon
  • mind_server (port 8080) â€” memory/knowledge retrieval with FTS
  • bridge_worker â€” background queue processor
  • cognitive_learner â€” pattern learning engine
  • advisory_synthesizer â€” multi-LLM advisor
  • observatory/explorer â€” analytics and pattern visualization

Executive Summary

Security posture is above average for a local-first tool. Built-in CSRF protection, Bearer token auth, localhost-binding, rate limiting, and a custom SAST tool. No critical RCE or data exfiltration vulnerabilities found.
SeverityCountSummary
HIGH2API key handling issues
MEDIUM6Tokens, auth bypass, race conditions, code execution paths
LOW4Data integrity, input validation, info disclosure
INFO2Positive findings + dependency analysis

HIGH Findings (2)

1. Gemini API Key Exposed in URL Query Parameter

File: lib/advisory_synthesizer.py:794

f"https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com/v1beta/models/{GEMINI_MODEL}:generateContent?key={GEMINI_API_KEY}"

Key appears in HTTP server logs, proxy logs, debug traces, and network monitoring. All other providers correctly use HTTP headers.

Fix: Use x-goog-api-key header instead.

2. API Keys Loaded from Repository .env File

File: lib/advisory_synthesizer.py:56-85

All API keys (OpenAI, Anthropic, Gemini, MiniMax) loaded from .env in the repo root. While in .gitignore, git add -f would expose everything. Keys propagated to all child daemon processes.

Fix: Add pre-commit hook; consider keyring/secrets manager.

MEDIUM Findings (6)

3. Token Files Written World-Readable

Files: mind_server.py, sparkd.py â€” _resolve_token()

Auto-generated Bearer tokens written to ~/.spark/*.token with default permissions (0644). Any local user can read them.

Fix: TOKEN_FILE.chmod(stat.S_IRUSR | stat.S_IWUSR) after write.

4. Remote POST Bypass via Environment Variable

Files: mind_server.py:305, sparkd.py:573

Setting MIND_ALLOW_REMOTE_POST=1 disables localhost-only POST protection entirely with no IP allowlist.

Fix: Implement IP allowlist rather than boolean toggle.

5. PID Lock File Race Condition (TOCTOU)

Check-then-write pattern. Between checking if lock exists and writing the new PID, another process could do the same â€” leading to duplicate daemon instances and data corruption.

Fix: Use os.open() with O_CREAT | O_EXCL or fcntl.flock().

6. ast.literal_eval on Database Values

File: lib/observatory/explorer.py (lines 941, 954, 1038, 1089, 1170)

Called on SQLite values. Crafted deeply-nested structures could cause memory exhaustion DoS.

Fix: Use json.loads() instead; validate string length before parsing.

7. Partial Path Resolution for Subprocess

The claude CLI resolved via PATH lookup without validation. A malicious binary in a writable PATH directory could be executed.

Fix: Use shutil.which("claude") and validate against expected locations.

8. No HTTPS/TLS on HTTP Servers

Plain HTTP on localhost. Acceptable for single-user; problematic if ALLOW_REMOTE_POST is enabled.

LOW Findings (4)

#FindingImpact
9Non-atomic file writes (no write-then-rename)Data corruption on crash during write
10No field-level length validation on API inputsMinor storage waste
11File lock staleness relies on filesystem mtimePotential deadlocks on network/container mounts
12Internal error details leaked in HTTP responses (str(e)[:200])Info disclosure

Positive Security Findings

  • Bearer token auth on all mutating endpoints
  • Cryptographically secure token generation (secrets.token_urlsafe(24))
  • Localhost-only binding by default
  • CSRF protection via Sec-Fetch-Site + Origin/Referer validation
  • Rate limiting (240 req/min sliding window)
  • Parameterized SQL throughout (no SQL injection)
  • No shell=True, no pickle, no eval/exec
  • Built-in SAST tool (public_release_safety_check.py)
  • Safety guardrails engine blocking destructive bash commands

Architecture Analysis

Pattern: File-Based Microservices â€” components communicate via JSONL queues, JSON state files, and SQLite. Resilient to partial failure, easy to debug, no service mesh required.

StrengthDetail
Robust Queue SystemOverflow protection, size limits, quarantine for invalid events
Multi-LLM AdvisorySynthesizes advice from OpenAI, Anthropic, Gemini, MiniMax in parallel
WeaknessDetail
God Function: run_bridge_cycleSingle massive function handling all event processing, pattern detection, learning, and advisory generation
Single-Threaded sparkdHandles requests one at a time â€” bottleneck under multi-agent load
Hardcoded Regex Noise FiltersPattern matching uses hardcoded regexes that become stale as usage patterns change

entries.title_en: Task Recovery System Proposal â€” Two-Layer Watchdog
entries.summary_en: Proposal for a zero-token, two-layer recovery system to handle Spark's silent delivery failures to Telegram. Layer 1 is a log-based watchdog (cron every 2 minutes, zero changes to Spark) that detects failed sends and alerts via direct Telegram API. Layer 2 is a task ledger (JSONL) that saves full response content before delivery, enabling actual result recovery.
entries.details_en:
The Problem

Spark (OpenClaw on 77.90.40.84, container openclaw-gateway) sometimes finishes work but can't deliver the response to Telegram due to intermittent network errors:
  • TypeError: fetch failed
  • sendChatAction failed: Network request failed

The work gets done â€” files created, code written â€” but the user never sees the result. OpenClaw does not retry failed sends. This is a silent failure.

Proposed Solution: Two-Layer Recovery

LayerNameToken CostChanges to SparkWhat Gets Recovered
Layer 1Log-Based WatchdogZeroNoneAlert notification only
Layer 2Task LedgerZeroMinimal (TOOLS.md instructions)Full response content

Layer 1: Log-Based Watchdog

A Python cron script parses Docker logs every 2 minutes, detects failed deliveries automatically with zero changes to Spark.

  1. Runs every 2 minutes via cron
  2. Pulls last 5 minutes of Docker logs from openclaw-gateway
  3. Finds all embedded run done events
  4. Checks for sendChatAction failed or fetch failed within 30 seconds after each run
  5. If failure detected â€” sends direct Telegram API alert, bypassing OpenClaw entirely
  6. Dedup via log file to avoid alert spam
#!/usr/bin/env python3
"""Spark Task Recovery Watchdog - Layer 1: Log Scanner"""
import subprocess, re, json, urllib.request
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

BOT_TOKEN = "THE_TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN"
CHAT_ID   = "1806088781"
LEDGER    = "/root/recovery_watchdog/last_check.txt"

logs = subprocess.check_output(
    ["docker", "logs", "openclaw-gateway", "--since", "5m"],
    stderr=subprocess.STDOUT, text=True
)
lines     = logs.split('\n')
run_dones = [l for l in lines if 'embedded run done' in l]
failures  = [l for l in lines if 'sendChatAction failed' in l
                               or 'fetch failed'          in l]
if run_dones and failures:
    msg = "I finished a task but had trouble delivering the result.\n"
    msg += "Please check the chat or ask me to repeat the last task."
    # send via direct Telegram API...

Cron entry: */2 * * * * /usr/bin/python3 /root/recovery_watchdog/watchdog.py

Layer 2: Task Ledger

Spark gets instructions via TOOLS.md to log every task in a JSONL ledger and save the full response before attempting Telegram delivery.

# Entry 1: Task started
{"ts": 1740300000, "id": "task_001", "source": "telegram",
 "task": "build landing page", "status": "started"}

# Entry 2: Task done, result saved
{"ts": 1740300180, "id": "task_001",
 "status": "done", "delivered": false,
 "result_file": "/root/task_results/task_001.md"}

# Entry 3: Successfully delivered
{"ts": 1740300181, "id": "task_001", "status": "delivered"}

What Needs to Be Built

#ItemLocation
1watchdog.py/root/recovery_watchdog/watchdog.py
2Results directory/root/task_results/
3Ledger file/root/task_ledger.jsonl (auto-created)
4Cron entrySpark server crontab â€” */2 * * * *
5TOOLS.md updateSpark's OpenClaw workspace

Cost Analysis

ResourceCost
LLM tokensZero
Storage~1 KB per ledger entry, ~10 KB per saved response
CPUNegligible (<1 second every 2 minutes)
Network1 Telegram API call only when recovery is triggered

Alternatives Rejected

AlternativeReason Rejected
Using LLM to analyze conversationsExpensive in tokens, adds latency, overkill for a delivery problem
Modifying OpenClaw source (add retry)Cleanest fix but risks breaking on updates, requires deep internals knowledge

Executive Summary

Complete bilingual recap of the ~8-hour session on Feb 22. Covers: OpenClaw gateway fix, Telegram bot going rogue (voice note + whisper install), Smart Router model switch (GLM-5 â†’ council/router/auto), Twitter following list scrape (2,244 accounts), and all config changes.

Full Report

# ×¡×©×Ÿ ×¡×™×›×•× â€” Session Recap 2026-02-22 ## ~8 ×©×¢×•×ª ×¢×‘×•×“×” / ~8 Hours of Work --- # ENGLISH SECTION ## Overview This document covers everything discussed, built, discovered, and fixed during the ~8-hour session on 2026-02-22. It includes all explanations, decisions, and reasoning â€” not just the outcomes. --- ## 1. Logan Integration Plan â€” The Email We Sent at the Start Before doing anything else, we analyzed the [whatsapp-public-logan](https://github.com/Nadav-Fux/whatsapp-public-logan) GitHub repo and sent a bilingual report to nadavf@gmail.com. **What Logan is:** A WhatsApp group management bot built for Israeli communities. It has: daily AI summaries, Shabbat auto-lock/unlock, spam detection (2-strike system), voice transcription via Groq Whisper, @mention AI responses, web search, message archival to a SQLite DB, join request bot-detection, and a broadcast system. **Integration decisions made:** - âœ… INTEGRATE: Message archival (SQLite/PostgreSQL â€” foundation for everything) - âœ… INTEGRATE: Daily summaries (high visible value, WA+TG) - âœ… INTEGRATE: Voice transcription (Groq Whisper, already have GROQ_API_KEY) - âœ… INTEGRATE: Spam detection (simplified â€” AI-based) - âœ… INTEGRATE: Shabbat lock/unlock (Hebcal API, deprioritized) - âŒ SKIP: Supabase auth state (Spark uses file-based auth) - âŒ SKIP: Logan's Express server (wa_daemon.js already has HTTP API) - âŒ SKIP: Logan's Groq-only LLM (Spark has multi-model via Council router) **Spark's advantages over Logan:** 1. Real-time message handling (not polling) 2. Simpler stack (no external DB dependency needed) 3. Multi-model AI via LLM Council router 4. Cross-platform native (WA + TG from day 1) 5. Already has HTTP API, no new servers needed **PRD addition:** The community OS PRD was updated with a full implementation plan adding Tier 0â€“6 features (message archival â†’ summaries â†’ voice â†’ catchup â†’ moderation â†’ engagement â†’ analytics â†’ monetization). --- ## 2. TTS + STT Implementation â€” Voice In, Voice Out **Why we built it:** Logan had STT. Spark had nothing. The PRD requires it for summaries, Vibe-Cast, and voice interaction. **STT (Speech-to-Text):** - Tool: **Groq Whisper** (`whisper-large-v3-turbo`) - Script: `/root/spark-groups/voice_transcriber.py` - Flow: User sends voice note â†’ wa_daemon.js detects `audioMessage` â†’ downloads OGG â†’ passes to voice_transcriber.py â†’ Groq API â†’ transcription returned - Hebrew auto-detected. Responds in Hebrew by default. - OpenClaw's `openai-whisper-api` skill was PATCHED to point to Groq's endpoint instead of OpenAI (because OpenAI costs money, Groq is free/fast) **TTS (Text-to-Speech):** - Tool: **Microsoft Edge TTS** (free, no API key, runs locally) - Script: `/root/spark-groups/voice_synthesizer.py` - Hebrew voices: `he-IL-AvriNeural` (male), `he-IL-HilaNeural` (female) - Output: OGG Opus format (WhatsApp and Telegram compatible) - WhatsApp `/tts` endpoint: `POST http://localhost:3500/tts` with `{"text": "...", "to": "972559741478"}` **WA Behavior:** Voice note IN â†’ STT transcription sent as reply â†’ if it's a DM, Spark also generates AI response â†’ sends AI response as TTS voice note back. Full voice-in/voice-out loop. **TG Behavior:** Transcription via `openai-whisper-api` skill (Groq-patched). TTS available but NOT automatic â€” Spark uses it when it decides to, not on every message. **Round-trip test result:** Sent "×©×œ×•× ×¢×•×œ×, ×× ×™ ×¡×¤××¨×§" â†’ STT returned "×©×œ×•× ×¢×•×œ×, ×× ×™ ×¡×¤×¨×§." (minor spelling difference â€” fully acceptable). --- ## 3. OpenClaw Update: 2026.2.9 â†’ 2026.2.21-2 **Problem:** npm 10.9.4 had a bug (`Cannot read properties of null (reading 'matches')`) that caused `npm install openclaw@latest` to fail. **Fix:** Upgraded npm itself from 10.9.4 â†’ 11.10.1 first, then cleared conflicting pnpm artifacts from `node_modules/.pnpm/`, then ran `npm install openclaw@latest --legacy-peer-deps`. **Memory situation during update:** RAM hit 86% during the install. Actions taken: - Expanded swap from 1.5 GB â†’ 4.0 GB (swap is a file `/swap.img`, easy to resize) - Cleared npm cache (~3 GB freed) - Compressed the 3.0 GB OpenClaw backup to 1.1 GB (63% reduction) - Final state: 14 GB disk free, 4 GB swap, system stable --- ## 4. GLM-5 Switch â€” Why and How **Why GLM-5 over GLM-4.7:** - Same ZAI API key, no extra cost - 200K context window (vs standard context) - Smarter base model with built-in deep thinking capability **The critical discovery â€” `thinkingDefault`:** - `"off"` â†’ crashes GLM-5 on ZAI API (returns `abort` error immediately) - `"disabled"` â†’ invalid value (OpenClaw rejects it) - `"low"` â†’ works perfectly, fast responses with light reasoning - `"high"` â†’ works but slow â€” 5-8 minutes per response (this is what broke the Telegram bot) **So what is `thinkingDefault`?** It controls how much token budget GLM-5 gets for internal reasoning BEFORE writing its answer. Think of it like "how long should Spark think before speaking." `low` = quick thought, `high` = deep analysis taking minutes. **Decision:** `thinkingDefault: "low"` as default. The smart router routes complex tasks to GLM-5 anyway; the thinking happens via model selection, not thinking budget. --- ## 5. The Telegram Bot Going Rogue â€” Root Cause **Symptom:** User sent a voice message to Spark on Telegram. It acts as an OpenAI-compatible endpoint and routes requests to the best available model based on context length and complexity. **The three routing modes:** - `council/router/auto` â†’ auto-selects tier based on message length and content - `council/router/fast` â†’ forces Tier 1 (lightweight fast models) - `council/router/smart` â†’ forces Tier 2/3 (capable/thinking models) **Model Tiers:** - **Tier 1 (Fast):** Gemini Flash, Groq 8B, Cerebras 8B â€” for simple quick questions - **Tier 2 (Smart):** Gemini 3.1 Pro High/Low, Groq 70B, NVIDIA 405B, Kimi K2, GLM-5 â€” for complex tasks - **Tier 3 (Deep):** GLM-5, GLM-4.7, Nemotron 49B â€” for hardest tasks - **Large Context:** Gemini 3.1 Pro (1M ctx), Kimi K2 (262K ctx), NVIDIA, GLM-5 (200K ctx) â€” for very long conversations **Routing logic (auto mode):** - Context > 8,000 tokens â†’ Large Context tier (skips Cerebras which only has 8K ctx) - Message contains code/analyze/explain/plan/strategy/translate/summary or is >1000 chars â†’ Smart tier - Otherwise â†’ Fast tier **Explicit model keywords** (start message with these): - `flash` / `×¤×œ××©` â†’ Gemini Flash - `pro` / `×¤×¨×•` â†’ Gemini 3.1 Pro High - `sonnet` / `×¡×•× ×˜` â†’ Claude Sonnet - `opus` / `××•×¤×•×¡` â†’ Claude Opus - `glm` â†’ GLM-5 **The relationship between router and thinkingDefault:** The router decides WHICH model to use. `thinkingDefault` controls how much GLM-5 reasons when it IS used. Critical Bug: Smart Router Stripped All Tool Definitions **The problem (explains why Spark couldn't build the landing page):** When OpenClaw routes through `council/router/auto`, it sends the request to the council API at port 8001. The council receives tool definitions (exec, write, process, browser) from OpenClaw â€” but was SILENTLY DROPPING THEM before forwarding to the actual model. **Root cause â€” 3 levels of stripping:** 1. `main.py` â€” `ChatCompletionRequest` pydantic model had `extra = "ignore"` and NO `tools` field â†’ tools stripped at intake 2. `smart_router.py` â€” `route_and_execute()` only received `messages` and `requested_model` â†’ no tools parameter at all 3. `openrouter.py` â€” `_query_provider()` built payload as `{"model": ..., "messages": ..., "temperature": 0.4}` â†’ no tools key â†’ model never saw tools **Result:** Spark sent "build me a landing page and put it on a subdomain" â†’ router selected Groq â†’ Groq received the request with NO tool definitions â†’ couldn't exec, couldn't write files â†’ failed. **The fix (3 files patched):** 1. `main.py` â€” Added `tools: Optional[List] = None` and `tool_choice: Optional[Any] = None` to `ChatCompletionRequest` 2. `smart_router.py` â€” Added `tools` and `tool_choice` parameters to `route_and_execute()`, passed to every `query_model()` call 3. `openrouter.py` â€” Added `tools` and `tool_choice` to `_query_provider()` signature, included in payload when provided, and added `tool_calls` passthrough in responses Also fixed: when a model returns `tool_calls` (not text), the router now properly includes them in the response with `finish_reason: "tool_calls"` instead of dropping them. **Verified:** Sent test request with tools to council â†’ model received tools â†’ responded correctly. --- ## 11. System Overview **Spark** (×¡×¤××¨×§ / ×¡×¤××¨×§×™, emoji: âš¡) is an autonomous AI personal assistant running on a private VPS at 77.90.40.84. It is built on **OpenClaw** (version 2026.2.9), an AI agent runtime that provides multi-channel communication, tool execution, skill loading, model routing, and persistent memory. Spark is NOT a chatbot. It is an autonomous agent capable of: - Executing shell commands on the server - Managing files, DNS, Cloudflare, domains, and tunnels - Sending/receiving email via AgentMail - Searching the web (SerpAPI, Jina AI MCP) - Scraping data (Apify) - Running automation workflows (n8n) - Speaking and listening (TTS/STT via Edge TTS and Groq Whisper) - Receiving and processing documents from WhatsApp/Telegram **User:** Nadav (Israel) â€” manages the system as sole operator. **Primary contact channels:** Telegram (@Nadav_molt_bot / ID: 7694920368), WhatsApp (+972559741478). **OpenClaw primary model:** council/router/auto (the Smart Router, see Section 4). **Chairman model:** ZAI GLM-5 (200K context, synthesizes final council responses). --- ## 2. Do not add back without re-testing. **Verified:** 2026-02-17 --- ## Appendix A: Quick Reference â€” Supervisord Commands ```bash # Check status of all processes docker exec openclaw-gateway supervisorctl \ -c /etc/supervisor/conf.d/supervisord.conf status # Restart individual processes docker exec openclaw-gateway supervisorctl \ -c /etc/supervisor/conf.d/supervisord.conf restart whatsapp-daemon docker exec openclaw-gateway supervisorctl \ -c /etc/supervisor/conf.d/supervisord.conf restart smart-router docker exec openclaw-gateway supervisorctl \ -c /etc/supervisor/conf.d/supervisord.conf restart openclaw docker exec openclaw-gateway supervisorctl \ -c /etc/supervisor/conf.d/supervisord.conf restart antigravity-proxy ``` ## Appendix B: Service Health Checks ```bash # WA Daemon status curl http://localhost:3500/status # Smart Router health (inside container) docker exec openclaw-gateway curl http://127.0.0.1:8001/health # OpenClaw gateway curl -H "Authorization: Bearer spark-gateway-2026" http://77.90.40.84:18789/v1/models # Antigravity proxy (inside container) docker exec openclaw-gateway curl http://127.0.0.1:8082/health # WA daemon log docker exec openclaw-gateway tail -50 /tmp/wa_daemon.log # Smart router log docker exec openclaw-gateway tail -50 /root/llm-council/backend.log # Antigravity log docker exec openclaw-gateway tail -50 /root/antigravity-proxy.log ``` ## Appendix C: Container Restart Procedure ```bash # Safe restart (preserves container and volume) docker restart openclaw-gateway # If container must be recreated (use only when necessary): # Step 1: backup wa_daemon.js to volume FIRST docker exec openclaw-gateway cp /root/wa_daemon.js /root/.openclaw/wa_daemon.js.backup # Step 2: also backup council files docker exec openclaw-gateway tar czf /root/.openclaw/llm-council-backup.tar.gz /root/llm-council/ # Step 3: recreate container docker stop openclaw-gateway && docker rm openclaw-gateway docker run ... (with correct volume mounts) # Step 4: restore wa_daemon.js docker exec openclaw-gateway cp /root/.openclaw/wa_daemon.js.backup /root/wa_daemon.js ``` ## Appendix D: Send Test Messages ```bash # WhatsApp text to Nadav curl -X POST http://localhost:3500/send \ -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \ -d '{"to":"972559741478","text":"Spark online."}' # WhatsApp to main group curl -X POST http://localhost:3500/post \ -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \ -d '{"group":"main","text":"Test message from Spark."}' # Telegram to bots channel TG_TOKEN="8518415361:AAFubmo8pes9XQ2vx1trCob3vfcKyMe_EMc" curl -X POST "https://api.telegram.org/bot${TG_TOKEN}/sendMessage" \ -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \ -d '{"chat_id":"-1003803854988","text":"Spark online."}' ``` --- *This document was generated on 2026-02-22.* *Update this file whenever architecture changes: models are added/removed, services are modified, new integrations are added, or bugs are fixed.*

Executive Summary

6-hour debug session report: fixed OpenClaw gateway not responding, found and fixed the Telegram bot going rogue (thinkingDefault high â†’ low, TOOLS.md missing STT/TTS docs), switched Smart Router primary model, scraped Twitter following list. Includes TODO list of 10 items not yet tested.

Full Report

# Spark Session Debug & Changes Log **Date:** 2026-02-22 | **Duration:** ~6 hours --- ## 1. WHAT WE DID TODAY ### A. OpenClaw Gateway â€” Fixed Not Responding - After switching to GLM-5 and restarting the container, port 18790 was refusing connections - **Fix:** It recovered on its own (startup takes ~2â€“3 min). Added monitoring patience. ### B. Telegram Bot Going Rogue â€” Root Cause Found & Fixed **Problem:** Someone sent a voice note on Telegram. The bot: - Ran `which whisper` â†’ not found - Tried `import speech_recognition` â†’ not found - **Started pip installing openai-whisper** (full PyTorch model, GB-sized) - Spent 5â€“8 minutes running 30+ exec tool calls accomplishing nothing **Two root causes:** 1. `thinkingDefault: "high"` in openclaw.json â€” GLM-5 with high thinking burns massive token budget before every response. Each message took 5â€“8 minutes. 2. TOOLS.md had NO mention of `voice_transcriber.py` or `voice_synthesizer.py` â€” bot had no idea those existed. **Fixes applied:** - `thinkingDefault: "high"` â†’ `"low"` (NOTE: `"off"` and `"disabled"` both cause crashes with GLM-5 on ZAI API â€” tested and confirmed) - Updated TOOLS.md with full STT and TTS sections including explicit warnings: "DO NOT install whisper â€” the tool is already installed" - Enabled `openai-whisper-api` skill in openclaw.json, configured with Groq API key - Patched `/app/skills/openai-whisper-api/scripts/transcribe.sh` to use Groq endpoint + whisper-large-v3-turbo instead of OpenAI ### C. Smart Router â€” Switched Primary Model - Changed `agents.defaults.model.primary` from `zai/glm-5` â†’ `council/router/auto` - Updated `/root/llm-council/backend/config.py` (both container + host copy): - Removed broken Antigravity models (`gemini-3-pro-high` â†’ `gemini-3.1-pro-high`, `gemini-3.1-pro-low`) - Added GLM-5 to TIER_2, TIER_3, LARGE_CONTEXT_MODELS - Added GLM-5 as CHAIRMAN_MODEL (was GLM-4.7) - TIER_1 (routing dispatchers): Gemini Flash, Groq 8B, Cerebras 8B - TIER_2 (responders): Gemini 3.1 Pro High/Low, Groq 70B, NVIDIA 405B, Kimi K2, GLM-5 ### D. Twitter Following List â€” @nadavfux - Scraped via Apify (actor: `TKLtfBQ02rrtQYmUa` + `4hDLdHfNzjgnztFn2`) - Ran 2 scrape sessions (1000 + 1288 accounts), merged = 2,244 unique accounts - **Files saved:** `/root/nvision/nadavfux_following.csv` (652KB) + `.json` (2.1MB) - **Sent via:** WhatsApp (Spark), Email (nadavf@gmail.com), Telegram bot âœ“ - **Added `/send-doc` endpoint to wa_daemon.js** (NOT persisted to host â€” see RISKS below) - **Cost:** ~$0 (Apify free tier, $5/month credits) --- ## 2. KNOWN ISSUES & ANSWERS ### Smart Router â€” How It Actually Works ``` User message â†’ council/router/auto (primary) â†“ Stage 0: Fast TIER_1 model (Groq 8B / Gemini Flash) picks best TIER_2 models â†“ Routes to SINGLE best model (NOT full 3-stage council for /v1/chat/completions) â†“ Result returned Full council synthesis (3-stage: members â†’ critics â†’ chairman) = /api/council/query endpoint ``` **thinkingDefault: "low"** applies to whichever model the router selects. - If router picks Groq Llama â†’ thinking parameter ignored (not supported), fast response - If router picks GLM-5 â†’ thinking=low applied (small budget, still smart) - Router picks based on: task complexity, context length, query type **Context window:** Router excludes Cerebras (8K limit) for long contexts automatically (`LARGE_CONTEXT_THRESHOLD = 8000`). GLM-5 (200K), Kimi K2 (262K), NVIDIA (128K) are in LARGE_CONTEXT_MODELS. ### âš ï¸ TOOL USE WITH ROUTER â€” UNVERIFIED **CRITICAL UNKNOWN:** When the router picks Groq or NVIDIA instead of GLM-5, does OpenClaw forward tool definitions to those models? If not, Spark loses exec/write/browser capabilities for those messages. **This has NOT been tested.** ### GitHub Issue #23006 (OpenClaw paired device scope loss) - We READ about it: upgrade from 2026.2.15 â†’ 2026.2.19+ causes device re-pairing loop due to missing `operator.write` and `operator.read` scopes - Fix was merged in PR #23125 - **We did NOT verify if we're affected** â€” our version is 2026.2.21-2 which should include the fix, but we didn't confirm - If Spark starts showing "pairing required" errors, run: `openclaw devices rotate --device --role operator --scope operator.admin --scope operator.approvals --scope operator.pairing --scope operator.write --scope operator.read` ### Landing Page Task â€” Why It Failed When Spark was asked to build a landing page on a subdomain, it failed because: 1. `thinking=high` at the time â†’ went rogue, ran dozens of commands with no focus 2. Bot tried to install nginx from scratch, then got confused with Cloudflare 3. TOOLS.md didn't give a clear workflow for: static site â†’ nginx config â†’ Cloudflare DNS 4. **Probably also a tool-use routing issue** â€” if router sent the message to a model without tool forwarding - **NOT retested after fixes** â€” should be tested ### TTS â€” When Does Spark Respond With Voice? | Channel | STT (transcribe voice) | TTS (reply with voice) | |---|---|---| | WhatsApp | âœ… Automatic (wa_daemon.js detects audioMessage) | âœ… Automatic for DMs only | | Telegram | âš ï¸ Only if agent DECIDES to (guided by TOOLS.md) | âš ï¸ Only if agent DECIDES to (not automatic) | Telegram TTS is NOT automatic â€” Spark would need to recognize the request and use the curl command from TOOLS.md to send via Telegram Bot API. ### Does Spark Know About Apify? **NO.** Apify is not in TOOLS.md. The API key (`apify_api_***REDACTED***`) is only in MEMORY.md. Spark could NOT have done the Twitter scrape autonomously. **Should be added to TOOLS.md.** ### Does Spark Know Everything It Should? Currently documented in TOOLS.md: - âœ… Email (AgentMail) with API key + examples - âœ… Cloudflare (cf.sh script + API token + domains) - âœ… Web Search (SerpAPI) - âœ… n8n dashboard URL - âœ… STT â€” voice_transcriber.py (just added) - âœ… TTS â€” voice_synthesizer.py + WA + Telegram (just added) Missing from TOOLS.md: - âŒ Apify (API key + example usage) - âŒ `/send-doc` WhatsApp endpoint (just added to wa_daemon) - âŒ Available OpenClaw skills list - âŒ Python packages installed in container - âŒ Static site / nginx workflow for landing pages - âŒ Telegram Bot API direct usage --- ## 3. PERSISTENCE RISKS âš ï¸ | Change | Persists docker restart? | Persists docker rm+run? | |---|---|---| | openclaw.json (thinkingDefault, model, skills) | âœ… Yes (volume mounted) | âœ… Yes | | council/config.py (TIER lists, Antigravity) | âœ… Yes (saved to host) | âœ… Yes | | TOOLS.md (STT/TTS sections) | âœ… Yes (volume mounted) | âœ… Yes | | wa_daemon.js (/send-doc endpoint) | âœ… Yes (container layer) | âŒ NO â€” LOST | | openai-whisper-api patch (Groq URL) | âœ… Yes (container layer) | âŒ NO â€” LOST | | Backup of wa_daemon.js | âœ… /root/.openclaw/wa_daemon.js.backup | âœ… Yes | **Action needed:** Properly save wa_daemon.js to host (needs docker-compose volume mount for /root/wa_daemon.js) OR add /send-doc to the OpenClaw skill instead. --- ## 4. WHAT WAS NOT CHECKED / TODO - [ ] Test Telegram STT end-to-end (send voice note â†’ Spark transcribes) - [ ] Test Telegram TTS (Spark replies with voice) - [ ] Test landing page task again after fixes - [ ] Verify tool use works when router picks non-GLM-5 model - [ ] Verify GitHub issue #23006 not affecting us (check paired device scopes) - [ ] Add Apify to TOOLS.md - [ ] Add /send-doc WA endpoint to TOOLS.md - [ ] Add nginx/static site workflow to TOOLS.md - [ ] Make wa_daemon.js properly persisted to host volume - [ ] Test smart router picks GLM-5 for complex tasks vs Groq for simple --- ## 5. KEY FILE LOCATIONS | File | Path | |---|---| | OpenClaw config | `/home/openclaw-runner/.openclaw/openclaw.json` | | Council router config | `/root/llm-council/backend/config.py` (container) + `/root/.gemini/antigravity/scratch/llm-council/backend/config.py` (host) | | TOOLS.md | `/home/openclaw-runner/.openclaw/workspace/TOOLS.md` | | wa_daemon.js | `/root/wa_daemon.js` (container only â€” NOT host mounted) | | wa_daemon backup | `/root/.openclaw/wa_daemon.js.backup` | | Whisper patch backup | `/home/openclaw-runner/.openclaw/transcribe_groq_patched.sh` | | Twitter following list | `/root/nvision/nadavfux_following.csv` + `.json` | | PRD | `/root/nvision/PRD_AI_Community_Broadcast_OS.md` | | Architecture doc | `/root/nvision/SPARK_ARCHITECTURE.md` |

Complete Twitter following list for @nadavfux scraped via Apify: 2,244 unique accounts across 2 scrape sessions. 706 blue-verified (X Premium), 348 accounts with 1M+ followers, 1,058 with 100K+. CSV and JSON files saved, sent via WhatsApp, email, and Telegram. Cost: $0 (free tier).

Executive Summary

Detailed plan for integrating Logan (WhatsApp + Telegram group management system) into Spark. Covers: architecture design, message routing between channels, group admin features, moderation capabilities, scheduled messages, and analytics dashboard. Not yet implemented â€” awaiting prioritization.

Full Report

======================================================== LOGAN INTEGRATION INTO SPARK â€” DETAILED PLAN REPORT WhatsApp + Telegram Group Management System ======================================================== From: Spark AI System (sparkemail@agentmail.to) To: Nadav (nadavf@gmail.com) Date: 2026-02-21 â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â” TABLE OF CONTENTS 1. Executive Summary 2. Logan Analysis â€” What It Does 3. What We're Integrating (and What We're Skipping) 4. Architecture Design 5. Phase-by-Phase Implementation Plan 6. Improvements Over Original Logan 7. Telegram Strategy 8. Timeline & Verification 9. Hebrew Section (×—×œ×§ ×‘×¢×‘×¨×™×ª) â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â” 1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ Logan (github.com/Nadav-Fux/whatsapp-public-logan) is a WhatsApp group management bot designed for Israeli/Hebrew communities. It includes daily AI summaries, Shabbat auto-lock, spam detection, voice transcription, and more. We are integrating Logan's best features directly into Spark's existing wa_daemon.js (Baileys v7, port 3500, running inside openclaw-gateway on 77.90.40.84). LOGAN ANALYSIS â€” WHAT IT DOES â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ Logan's core features (from source code analysis): a) MESSAGE ARCHIVAL - Stores all group messages in a database - Tracks sender info, timestamps, media types - Foundation for summaries and analytics b) DAILY AI SUMMARIES - Summarizes group conversations at end of day - Uses LLM to generate structured Hebrew summaries - Categories: main topics, decisions, action items, stats c) SHABBAT AUTO-LOCK/UNLOCK - Fetches candle lighting & havdalah times from Hebcal API - Friday: Sends "×©×‘×ª ×©×œ×•×", locks group (admin-only mode) - Saturday night: Sends "×©×‘×•×¢ ×˜×•×‘", reopens group - Erev Shabbat awareness (adjusts behavior on Fridays) d) VOICE TRANSCRIPTION - Detects voice messages in groups - Downloads audio, converts via ffmpeg - Sends to Groq Whisper API (whisper-large-v3-turbo) - Replies with Hebrew transcription e) SPAM DETECTION - 2-strike system: first offense = warning, second = kick - Pattern matching (suspicious URLs, spam phrases) - AI-powered judgment for ambiguous cases f) @MENTION AI RESPONSES - When someone @mentions the bot, it responds with AI - Uses conversation context from recent messages g) JOIN REQUEST PROCESSING - Bot-detection for new join requests - Auto-approve/reject based on criteria h) BROADCAST SYSTEM - Send messages to multiple groups - Duplicate prevention â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â” 3.
